solution.text:
Volume of the brick wall \(= 13 m \times 3 m \times 0.5 m = 19.5 m^3\)
Volume of one brick \(= 20 cm \times 10 cm \times 5 cm = 1000 cm^3\)
\(1 m^3 = 1000000 cm^3\)
Therefore, number of bricks required \(= 19.5 \times \frac{1000000}{1000}\)
\(= 19500\)

content.text: Anjali is building a brick wall which is 13 m long, 3m tall and 50cm wide. Each brick is 20cm long, 10 cm wide and 5 cm tall. How many bricks will Anjali need to buy?

hint.text: Start by calculating the volume of the entire brick wall

solution.text:
Area of Garden = Area of Plot - Area of the House
\(= ab - cd\)
\(= (4240 - 50(10)) m^2\)
\(=3740 m^2\)

content.text: Kshitij is looking to landscape his garden. He made a diagram of his house (grey colour) but forgot to mention the exact dimensions of the garden area. You are the engineer in charge of the project. Can you use the information given below to calculate the area of the garden? a = 106 m, b = 40 m, c = 50 m, d = 10 m

hint.text: Try subtracting areas to find the right answer

solution.text:
Given the area \(= \frac 12 \times Width \times\) (Sum of parallel sides)
\(= \frac 12 \times 27 \times (23 +\) River Side Length\()\)
Therefore River Side Length = \(\frac{1120.5}{13.5} - 23\)
\(= 60 m\)

content.text: Hussain bought a plot of agricultural land which is in the shape of a trapezium (see below). The area of the land is \(1120.5 m^2\), the side parallel to the road is 23 metres and the width of the field is 27 metres. How long is the side parallel to the river?

hint.text: The area of a trapezium is \(\frac 12 \times Height \times\) (Sum of parallel sides)

solution.text:
Area of school floor \(= 4598 m^2\)
Area of each tile = \(Base \times height = 19 \times 11 = 209 cm^2\)
Since the tiles can be perfectly broken into smaller parts, the number of tiles required is the area of the floor divided by the area of each tile. Also, remember that \(1m^2 = 10000 cm^2\)
Therefore, Number of tiles = 220000

content.text: The area of your school library floor is \(4598 m^2\). You are asked to use tiles in the shape of a parallelogram with a base of 19 cm and a height of 11 cm to cover the floor. How many such tiles will you need to purchase? You can break the tiles in any way to cover the entire floor.

hint.text: Start by finding the area of each tile.

solution.text:
Area of tin sheet required for 1 box = Surface area of one box
\(= 2 (6 \times 7 + 7 \times 8 + 6 \times 8) = 292 cm^2\)
Therefore, area of tin required for 10 boxes \(= 292 \times 10\)
\(= 2920 cm^2\)

\(= 785.71\) L

solution.text:
Curved Surface area of the roller \(= 2 \pi rh = 2\pi \times \frac {6}2 \times 34 = 641.14 cm^2\)
Area covered per rotation \(= 641.14 cm^2\)
\(\Rightarrow\) Area painted in 58 rolls \(= 641.14 \times 58 = 37186.29 cm^2\)

content.text: Last Monday, Ram painted a rectangular wall with a cylindrical paint roller. The length of the roller is 34 cm and its diameter is 6 cm. While painting, the roller rolled over 58 times completely. What surface area did Ram paint?

hint.text: How much area does the roller cover in one rotation?

content.text: The dimensions of a cuboid are in the ratio of 6:5:2 (l:b:h). If the total surface area is 1664 \(m^2\). What is the length of the cuboid?
What is the Breadth of the cuboid?

solution.text:
Let length:breadth:height = 6x:5x:2x
Therefore, Surface Area of the cuboid = \(2(6 \times 5x^2 + 5 \times 2x^2 + 2 \times 6x^2)\)
= \(2(52)x^2\)
= \(104x^2\)
Given that surface area is \(1664 m^2\)
Therefore, \(1664 m^2 = 104 x^2\)
\(\Rightarrow x^2 = \frac{1664}{104}\)
\(\Rightarrow x = \sqrt{16}\)
\(\Rightarrow\) x = 4 metres

content.text: What is the Height of the cuboid?

hint.text: Surface Area of the cuboid = \(2 (lb + bh + lh)\)

solution.text:
Surface Area of the pipe = Curved surface area of outer cylinder + Curved surface area of inner cylinder + Area of both rims
\(= 2\pi {r_ o}h + 2\pi {r_ i}h + 2(\pi {r_ o}^2 - \pi {r_ i}^2)\)
\(= 2\pi \times \frac{23}2 \times 11 + 2 \pi \times \frac{7}2 \times 11 + 2\pi({\frac{23}2}^2 - {\frac{7}2}^2)\)
= 1791.43\(cm^2\)
Therefore, cost of painting the pipe \(= 1791.43 \times 0.2\)
= Rs. 358.29

content.text: A cylindrical pipe has an outer diameter of 23 cm and an inner diameter of 7 cm. Its length is 11 cm. It needs to be painted on its outer and inner surfaces, as well as the rims. The cost of painting the pipe is Rs. 0.2 per \(cm^2\). What is the total cost of painting the pipe?

hint.text: Surface Area of the pipe = Curved surface area of outer cylinder + Curved surface area of inner cylinder + Area of both rims

solution.text:
Volume of original tube = \((\pi{r_ o}^2 \times h) - (\pi{r_ i}^2 \times h)\)
\(= 3872 cm^3\)
Now, Volume of new tube = Volume of original tube
Let the length of the new tube be x
Therefore,\(V_ {new} = (\pi{r_ o}^2 \times h) - (\pi{r_ i}^2 \times h) = (\pi (\frac {13}{2})^2 \times x) - (\pi (\frac {13}{2} - 6)^2 \times x)\)
\(\Rightarrow x = \frac {V_ {original}}{\pi (\frac {13}2)^2-\pi (\frac {13}2 - m)^2}\)
= 29.33 cm

solution.text:
Area of Polygon = Area of Triangle (1) + Area of Trapezium (2) + Area of Triangle (3) + Area of Triangle (4) + Area of Triangle (5)
\(\frac 12 \times a \times b + \frac 12 (b + e)(c + d) + \frac 12 \times e \times f + \frac 12 \times g \times (d+f) + \frac 12 \times (a+c) \times g\)
\(= \frac 12 \times 6 \times 7 + \frac 12 \times 14.5 \times 10 + \frac 12 \times 7.5 \times 4.5 + \frac 12 \times 6 \times 7.5 + \frac 12 \times 13 \times 6\)
\(=180.875 cm^2\)

= Area of Trapezium \(\times 2\)
\(= \frac 12 (a+c)(h) \times 2\)
\(= \frac 12 (28.5 + 38)(19) \times 2\)
\(= 1263.5 mm^2\)

Find the area of the shapes below:

hint.text:
Observe the shapes carefully and see if you can break them down into smaller shapes to make calculating the areas easier. Remember the following formulas:
Area of Rectangle: \(length \times breadth\)
Area of Square: \(length^2\)
Area of a Triangle: \(\frac 12 \times base \times height\)
Area of Parallelogram: \(base \times height\)
Area of Trapezium: \(\frac 12 \times (a+b) \times h\)

solution.text:
Curved surface area (CSA) = \(2\pi rh\)
Total surface area = \(2\pi r (r+h) = 2\pi r^2 + 2\pi rh = 3 \times CSA = 4158\)
Therefore, \(2\pi r^2 + 2\pi rh = 6\pi rh\)
\(\Rightarrow 2\pi r^2 = 4\pi rh\)
\(\Rightarrow r = 2h\)
\(\Rightarrow h = \frac {r}{2}\)
\(CSA = \frac{4158}3 = 2\pi rh = 2\pi r(\frac {r}{2}) = \pi r^2\)
\(\Rightarrow\) Area of Base = \(\pi r^2 = \frac{4158}3\)
\(\Rightarrow r^2 = \frac {4158\times 7}{3\times 22}\)
\(\Rightarrow r = 21 cm\)
\(\Rightarrow h = \frac {r}{2} = 10.5 cm\)
Therefore, volume \(= \pi r^2h = 14553 cm^3\)

content.text: A solid cylinder has total surface area of 4158 square centimetres. Its curved surface area is one-third of its total surface area. Find the volume of the cylinder

solution.text:
Volume of cylinder \(= \pi r^2 \times h = \pi \times 9^2 \times 56 = 14256 cm^3\)
Volume of new cuboid = \(lbh\) = Volume of cylinder
Therefore, \(lbh = 14256 cm^3\)
\(\Rightarrow 31 \times 24 \times h = 14256 cm^3\)
\(\Rightarrow h = \frac {14256}{31 \times 24} = 19.16\)
The new cuboid is 19.16 cm tall

hint.text: If no metal is wasted, both objects will have the same volume.

=\(\frac{\sqrt{3}}{4}\times 1849 cm^2\)
Therefore, volume of water added = Area of base \(\times\) Rise in water Level
=119953.88 \(cm^3\)
Since 1L =\(1000cm^3\)
Volume of water added = 119.95 L

solution.text:
Given the volume of the pipe = V = 6109.71 \(cm^3\)
The volume of a cylindrical pipe = \(\pi{r_ o}^2h - \pi{r_ i}^2h\)
Let the thickness of the pipe be \(x\)
\(\Rightarrow V = \pi (15)^2 \times 24 - \pi (15-x)^2 \times 24\)
\(\Rightarrow \frac {V}{24\pi}=15^2 - (15-x)^2\)
\(\Rightarrow (15-x)^2 = 225 - \frac{V}{24\pi}\)
\(\Rightarrow x = 15 - 12\)
\(\Rightarrow x = 3\)
Therefore, the thickness of the pipe is 3 cm

Area of each face =\(3.3^2 cm^2\)
Number of faces that face inward = 10 faces
Therefore, outer surface area = 326.7 - 108.9 = 217.8 \(cm^2\)
Cost of paint = Rs 13 per \(cm^2\)
Therefore, total cost of painting the object = \(217.8 \times 13\)
= Rs. 2831.4

\(= \pi{r_ o}^2 \times h - \pi{r_ i}^2 \times h\)
\(= \pi (16)^2 \times 28 - \pi(12)^2 \times 28\)
= 9856\( cm^3\)
\(Mass = Volume \times Density\)
\(\Rightarrow Mass = 9856 cm^3 \times \frac{8.6 g}{cm^3}\)
= 84761.6 g

content.text: A cube has an edge measuring 30 cm. Find the number of cubes of edge 15 cm that can be cut off from it.

hint.text: Find the volume of the large cube and compare it to the volume of the smaller cube

solution.text:
Total Curved Surface Area = \(2\pi rh = 176 cm^2\)
\(\Rightarrow 2rh = \frac{176}{\pi} = 56 cm^2\)
Once you cut the slice, there are three faces without icing: The curved outer surface and the two rectangular inner surfaces. (Remember that the top and bottom surfaces have icing)
Also, length of Base of Slice = Radius of Cylinder and Height of Slice = Height of Cylinder
Therefore, area of the slice that has no icing
= Curved area of slice + 2 \(\times\) Rectangular surface area of slice
\(= \frac{1}{10}\)(Total Curved Surface Area) + 2 \(\times\) (Base \(\times\) Height of slice)
\(= \frac {1}{10}\times 176 + 2rh\)
\(= \frac {1}{10}\times 176 + 56\)
= 73.6 \(cm^2\)

Therefore, the volume will quarter

solution.text:
Cross section of river area = Area of 1 + Area of 2 \(= ac \times \frac 12 (d-c) (a+b) = 130 \times 28 + \frac 12 \times 45\times(130 + 100)\)
\(= 8815 m^2\)
Rate of flow = 2 km/hr = 2000 m/hr
Volume of water flow = Area of cross section \(\times\) Rate of flow
\(= 8815 \times 2000 = 17630000 m^3/hr\)
= 17630 megalitre/hr
One week = 7 days =\( 24 \times 7\) hours = 168 hours
Therefore, volume of water flowing into the sea in one week \(= 168 \times 17630\)
= 2961840 megalitres
